title: forge init circular dependency issue
body:
### Component

Forge

### Have you ensured that all of these are up to date?

- [X] Foundry
- [X] Foundryup

### What version of Foundry are you on?

forge 0.2.0

### What command(s) is the bug in?

forge init hello_foundry

### Operating System

Linux

### Describe the bug

There seems to be a circular dependency issue with `forge init hello_foundry` in an existing and empty git repo.

# Background

Most of my crypto work is anon, so I don't globally set my git credentials. I set them up per repo using scripts.

This is the reason why I'm running the above command in an empty folder that has already been initialised as a repo (an setup with correct user config). 

# Steps to replicate

> must make sure that git credentials are not set globally by running `git config --list | grep 'user.'`

1. Create a new folder 

2. Initialise that new folder as a git repo

3. Run `forge init hello_foundry` 

# Behaviour

Running the command ends in this error:

```
Installing forge-std in "/home/USER/foundry/hello_foundry/lib/forge-std" (url: Some("https://github.com/foundry-rs/forge-std"), tag: None)
Error: 
This command requires clean working and staging areas, including no untracked files. Modify .gitignore and/or add/commit first, or add the --no-commit option.

```

Quite a strange error as you can see: why would we get an unclean working area within an empty git repo?

After doing an ls in the repo it becomes clear what is happening.

```
hello_foundry

```

The folder for the project has been created and a downstream command has a clean repo requirement that is not satified.

But I'm also betting that the folder is required for upcoming steps, hence why I titled this - circular dependency.

# Workarounds

Trying to commit the newly created folder and then rerunning the `init` command does not work, resulting in: 

```
error: `forge init` cannot be run on a non-empty directory.

```

Running `forge init hello_foundry --force` also does not work, resulting in: 

```
Installing forge-std in "/home/USER/foundry/hello_foundry/lib/forge-std" (url: Some("https://github.com/foundry-rs/forge-std"), tag: None)
Error: 
fatal: pathspec '.gitmodules' did not match any files

```

# Outcome

Was not able to install the `hello-world` example because of the above issues
